abstract: Some members of the Bancroft family, which controls the company, said they planned to vote against the unsolicited bid.
snippet: Some members of the Bancroft family, which controls the company, said they planned to vote against the unsolicited bid.
lead_paragraph: The News Corporation, owner of the Fox News Channel and The New York Post, has made an unsolicited $5 billion takeover bid for Dow Jones, publisher of The Wall Street Journal.

headline.main: News Corp. Makes a $5 Billion Bid for Dow Jones

byline.original: By Jeremy W. Peters and Richard Siklos

abstract: The unsolicited offer could set in motion the kind of takeover saga that readers might find in The Wall Street Journal, the flagship publication of Dow Jones.
snippet: The unsolicited offer could set in motion the kind of takeover saga that readers might find in The Wall Street Journal, the flagship publication of Dow Jones.
lead_paragraph: In a bold move to expand his global media empire, Rupert Murdoch, the head of the News Corporation, has made an unsolicited $5 billion offer to buy Dow Jones & Company, the venerable publisher of The Wall Street Journal, which he has long coveted.

headline.main: Rupert Murdoch Offers $5 Billion Bid for Dow Jones
headline.print_headline: $5 Billion Bid From Murdoch For Dow Jones

byline.original: By Richard Siklos and Andrew Ross Sorkin

abstract: Rupert Murdoch made a bid so high and so lacking in the normal economics of deal-making, that he effectively scared away any potential competitors.
snippet: Rupert Murdoch made a bid so high and so lacking in the normal economics of deal-making, that he effectively scared away any potential competitors.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, with Dow Jones stock mired in the low 30s — and unhappy members of the controlling Bancroft family selling off some of their shares — Roy A. Hammer, the longtime trustee for the family, quipped to a reporter: “We’d rather sell at $60 a share. If you know any buyers, send them my way.”

headline.main: Dow Offer a Marvel in Its Timing

abstract: Rupert Murdoch made a bid for Dow Jones so high that it may begin moving the Bancroft family in his direction.
snippet: Rupert Murdoch made a bid for Dow Jones so high that it may begin moving the Bancroft family in his direction.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, with Dow Jones stock mired in the low 30s — and unhappy members of the controlling Bancroft family selling off some of their shares — Roy A. Hammer, the longtime trustee for the family, quipped to a reporter: “We’d rather sell at $60 a share. If you know any buyers, send them my way.”

headline.main: Now Murdoch Must Persuade the Family
headline.print_headline: Now Murdoch Must Persuade The Family

abstract: Has Rupert Murdoch made the Bancroft family an offer they can’t refuse?
lead_paragraph: Has Rupert Murdoch made the Bancroft family an offer they can’t refuse?

headline.main: Will the Bancrofts Sell Dow Jones?

abstract: As deal makers survey the media scene following News Corporation‘s offer for Dow Jones, one name that keeps popping up is Pearson, the British book publisher and owner of The Financial Times. There were lots of scenarios being laid out for Pearson, whose $14 billion market capitalization makes it about three times the size of Dow Jones. It could enter the bidding for Dow Jones. It could itself be a takeover target. It could break itself up.
lead_paragraph: As deal makers survey the media scene following News Corporation‘s offer for Dow Jones, one name that keeps popping up is Pearson, the British book publisher and owner of The Financial Times. There were lots of scenarios being laid out for Pearson, whose $14 billion market capitalization makes it about three times the size of Dow Jones. It could enter the bidding for Dow Jones. It could itself be a takeover target. It could break itself up.

headline.main: Dow Jones Bid Puts Pearson in Headlines

abstract: Many Wall Street analysts are still gaping over the $5 billion unsolicited bid that Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation made for Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal. At $60 per share, it was 67 percent above the company’s recent stock price and represented a multiple of about 16 times Dow Jones’s projected 2007 Ebitda. (Other recent newspaper deals have come in at about eight times Ebitda.) A former financial adviser to the Bancroft family, which controls Dow Jones, has called the bid “absolutely, insanely high.”
lead_paragraph: Many Wall Street analysts are still gaping over the $5 billion unsolicited bid that Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation made for Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal. At $60 per share, it was 67 percent above the company’s recent stock price and represented a multiple of about 16 times Dow Jones’s projected 2007 Ebitda. (Other recent newspaper deals have come in at about eight times Ebitda.) A former financial adviser to the Bancroft family, which controls Dow Jones, has called the bid “absolutely, insanely high.”

headline.main: One Investor’s Dow Jones Dream: $100 Per Share
